english: President Tsai Ing-wen's Apology to the Indigenous Peoples on Behalf of the Government.

english: On this day 22 years ago, the term "shanbao" (mountain people) in the Additional Articles of our Constitution was replaced with the proper name: "indigenous people." This correction not only did away with a discriminatory term, but also highlighted the status of indigenous peoples as Taiwan's "original owners." From this basis, today, we are taking another step forward. To all indigenous peoples of Taiwan: On behalf of the government, I express to you our deepest apology. For the four centuries of pain and mistreatment you have endured, I apologize to you on behalf of the government.

english: I know that even now, there are some around us who see no need to apologize. But that is the most important reason why I am representing the government to issue this apology today. To see what was unfair in the past as a matter of course, or to treat the pain of other ethnic peoples as an unavoidable part of human development, this is the first mindset that we, standing here today, resolve to change and overturn.

english: Let me put in simple terms why we are apologizing to the indigenous peoples. Four hundred years ago, there were already people living in Taiwan. These first inhabitants lived their lives and had their own languages, cultures, customs, and domains. But then, without their consent, another group of people arrived on these shores, and in the course of history, took everything from the first inhabitants who, on the land they have known most intimately, became displaced, foreign, non-mainstream, and marginalized.

english: The success of one ethnic people can be built on the suffering of another. Unless we deny that we are a country of justice, we must face up to this history. We must tell the truth. english: There is a book called "The General History of Taiwan" published in 1920. In its foreword are these words: "Taiwan had no history. The Dutch pioneered it, the Koxinga Kingdom built it, and the Qing Empire managed it." This is a typical Han view of history. The truth is that indigenous peoples have been here for thousands of years, with rich culture and wisdom that have been passed down through generations. But we only know to write history from the perspective of the dominant. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

english: The Dutch and the Koxinga Kingdom massacred and exploited the Pingpu ethnic group. The Qing Empire presided over bloody confrontations and suppression. Colonial Japan put in place comprehensive savage policies. And the post- war ROC government undertook assimilation policies. For 400 years, every regime that has come to Taiwan has brutally violated the rights of indigenous peoples through armed invasion and land seizure. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

english: Indigenous peoples maintain tribal order according to traditional customs, and ecological balance according to traditional wisdom. But in the process of modern state-building, indigenous peoples lost the right to steer their own course and govern their own affairs. The fabric of traditional societies was torn apart, and the collective rights of peoples were not recognized. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

english: Indigenous peoples had their own languages. However, with Japanese rule aiming to assimilate and turn all into imperial subjects, and with the ROC government banning tribal languages after 1945, indigenous peoples' languages suffered great losses. Most Pingpu languages have disappeared. Successive governments have been negligent in the protection of indigenous cultures. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

english: Without the knowledge of the Yami tribe, the government stored nuclear waste on Orchid Island. Tribe members on the island had to suffer the negative consequences. For this, I apologize to the Yami people on behalf of the government.

english: Ever since outsiders began arriving in Taiwan, the Pingpu ethnic group on the western plains have born the brunt of the impact. One ruling power after another eroded the individual and collective identities of the Pingpu ethnic group. For this, I apologize to the Pingpu ethnic group on behalf of the government.

For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

Today's apology is long overdue, but it is a beginning. I do not expect any one speech or phrase of apology to wipe away four centuries of pain and suffering by the indigenous peoples. But I do hope with all my heart that today's apology will set this country and all its people on the path towards reconciliation.

In other words, only by facing the truth sincerely can reconciliation be attained.

When this truth-telling concludes, the elder calls for everyone to drink together, so that what is past is truly past. This is "Sbalay."

But I sincerely ask you to sustain the hope that past wrongs will not be repeated, and that one day, this country can see true reconciliation.

As the head of state, I will serve as convener and work hand in hand with tribal representatives to pursue historical justice. We will also discuss, on the basis of equality, the future policy direction of this country.

We will step up the pace and submit for legislative deliberation three laws of great importance to indigenous peoples: the Indigenous Peoples Self-Government Law, the Indigenous Peoples Land and Sea Areas Law, and the Indigenous Languages Development Law.

sxr: mongahlʉ ako tomototoro ihlao tomamahlʉngʉ osoa ngahlana ringai.
english: Then I will teach you how to set up these two traps.

sxr: a'ʉ! tam mavacangʉ! aonani ia macahlia ako matiasangalʉ co a koli'i cocoari.
english: Great! I will be able to catch the prey in the future.

sxr: mʉlʉngʉsʉ angatʉ co a sʉsʉngʉ hlipatoaiiailia, mosa o risakʉ omala kakamalʉ, mosa mo hlipatoaiiailia.
english: The grass in the fields is too tall. Go to the warehouse to take the sickle and let's go to the fields.

sxr: ma patʉkʉ parangahlʉ, poaroma o risakʉna ia taratʉahlʉ co.
english: It is next to the round basket. You will see it when you enter the warehouse.

sxr: maiatohlohlo omala, kokia patahlivo. tam mavarʉvarʉ a kakamalʉna.
english: Be careful and don't get hurt. The sickle is very sharp.

sxr: ma kalahlapa palongo kio'o ringai ko.
english: My trap is under that tree.

sxr: ma ko nani patacokahlangʉ, macahlia ko maninao ringai ko.
english: I make a mark here, so I know where my trap is.

sxr: talahlʉ kani'ina, iko ako patʉkʉ hlohlongo pariavovotokohlo.
english: This is a fish trap which we put beside the river for fishing.

sxr: oka'a mo talahlʉ kaio, rianʉ oroamia iacapa mo matisangalʉ votokohlo.
english: We don't have any fish traps there, so we catch fish with a fishing rod.

sxr: oka'a ko hlioroamia iacapa, toahlʉ o i tomototoro ihlako mongahlʉ ari?
english: I have never used a fishing rod before, would you mind teaching me next time?

sxr: hla tomototoro ako ihlao tomamahlʉngʉ talahlʉ mongahlʉ ari.
english: I will teach you how to make a fish trap next time.

sxr: titipa co o iacapa, koi maro votokohlo pakakaihli co, pasakolai o rʉkʉcʉ.
english: Your fishing rod is moving. Isn't the fish on the hook? Pull it up!

sxr: cocovana, koatitipa co a 'avangʉna, ma ko naani rʉkʉcʉ iacapa, mosa o kaio tomalʉlʉviako alʉ sapoarʉ.
english: Wait, the ship is rolling heavily. I am here to pull the fishing rod and you should go there to grab me the net.

sxr: rʉkʉci o votokohlo oamia ko naani, tomalʉlʉvʉ ako ihlao rʉkʉcʉ.
english: Pull the fish to my side and I will help you pull it up.
Great! It is a bumper crop today with full fish baskets.

sxr: pasakolai mo poaili poposoa pahlomiamia coco mʉmʉa.
english: Let's go back immediately and share it with everyone.
Stop playing and quickly sit in your seat.

sxr: takoalimaʉ a arinani, taloavaʉlʉ a matata, kiʉlʉsʉaita moromita vahlita pasaolaola'ʉ!
english: It's Friday today, we have a day off tomorrow. Let's go out and play together!
Great! Let's go to the riverside.
What day will it be tomorrow?

sxr: takoatoloaʉ matata, mosalaitamao kʉlʉpʉngʉ komamahlipapo matata pasaolaola'ʉ taʉhlʉkai!
english: Tomorrow will be Wednesday. Let's go play ball tomorrow afternoon!
What will you be doing tomorrow morning?

sxr: taloavaʉlana ari matata, moasalako mʉlʉvʉ ina'a mahlokoa parana tapakiana.
english: Tomorrow will be Sunday, I will be going to church with my mom.
I feel like vomiting. I need to go to the restroom.

sxr: pakiatoroa, macarʉmʉ a civokako, moasako tatiahla.
english: Teacher, I have a stomachache. I need to go to the restroom.
May I go wash my hands?
It's almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.

sxr: pakiatoroa, tam macarʉmʉ a vongoko, taloavaʉlʉako kʉlʉpʉngʉ komamahlipapo.
english: It's almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.
Okay, take care and go home.

sxr: pakiatoroa, taloavaʉlʉako moangahlangahla takoacaniaʉ aari, moasaako pakita maisasavosavoanʉ.
english: Teacher, I need to take a sick leave next Monday. I have to see a doctor.

sxr: macarʉmʉ a civokaisa kana'ana, ma tatiahla kana'ana.
english: She has a stomachache. She's in the restroom.

sxr: pakiatoroa, macarʉmʉ a alʉmʉsaisa Taahlʉna, talovaʉlʉ arinani.
english: Teacher, Taahlʉna has a sore throat. She took a sick leave today.

sxr: ngahlako ia Hlakota'i savaoana, maahlʉ a caihliko mamisa.
english: My name is Hlakuta'i savauana, and I'm 10 years old.
What ethnic group are you from?
Are all your family members indigenous?
Yes, my whole family is Hla′alua.

sxr: tʉkʉhlʉ, amako ia Hla'aloa, inako ia Pakisia'a.
english: No, my father is Hla′alua, and my mother is Han Taiwanese.

sxr: amao i kana'ana? taininico a caihlisa?
english: Is that your father? How old is he?

sxr: tʉkʉhlʉ, kana'ana ia hlamamaisa miararomahlamo, malʉhlico a caihlisa kana'ana.
english: No, he is an elder of our tribe. He is 80 years old.

sxr: laihla oalo a caihlisa ahlaloako hlahlosa.
matatanini a caihlisa ahlaloao hlahlosa ihlao?
english: Is your brother much older than you?
I haven't seen you in a while. Have you grown taller?
I'm going to the office to see the teacher.
He's going to throw away the trash.

sxr: ma parana makahlangolo a kana'ana, tarisia kana'ana cocovanana makahlangolo.
english: He's at the swimming pool. He's going to compete in a swimming competition later.

sxr: ini paninao a Na'apʉ? tarisia kana'ana cocovanana mitahlahlʉ.
english: Where is Na'apʉ? She's going to compete in a running competition later.

sxr: ma kana'ana parana taroacocovongana, mosako makihlohloisana.
english: She's in the auditorium. I'll go call her.
Let's go to the playground together.

sxr: moasako moaloalo po'a koamamahlipapo, cocovanana oakikirimi ihlao.
english: I'll go buy lunch first, and then I'll meet you later.
Let's carry the lunch boxes together!

sxr: okikirimamao coco'o osomanʉ, moasako okikirimi pakiatoroa.
english: You find someone else, I'm going to find the teacher.
Is Tautauna competing in croquet today?
No, he's competing in high jump.

sxr: aari kana'a korarao sikoatitipana kiapohloo i tarisia?
english: Will you compete in the sports day?

sxr: ngasa tarisiahlamo aari kana'a korarao sikoatitipana?
english: What will we do in the sports day?
We will compete in tug of war.
Will we sell food at the sports day?
Congratulations on getting first place! You're amazing!
Yes, she's sleeping in her room.

sxr: oka'a, mosa moromita a kana'ana kicovanana, corovanaco iniciki poaili.
english: No, she's not. She just went out and will be back in the evening.

sxr: ma hlikico langica a kana'ana, coomao kikirimo kana'ana.
english: He's upstairs. You can go up and find him.

sxr: ihlaisao'iao Pali, rahlooacoo koakitikiti, mavacangio i?
english: It's Pali. I haven't seen you in a while! How have you been?
I'm doing great! I came to chat with you.

sxr: ma tavava a kana'ana omangʉangʉrarʉ camai, moasako makihlohloisana.
english: He's in the kitchen cooking. Let me go call him.

sxr: mosa a kana'ana tatorokokana matisangalʉ torokoka.
english: She went to the chicken coop to catch chickens.

sxr: kopa salia a tamomo hlahlosa, ma omoma, marokia ihlamo salia opapaloisana poaili.
english: Your grandfather is not at home. He's in the field. Wait for him to come back.
I haven't seen you in a while. You've grown taller.
It's so good to see you.
Here's a pineapple for you. Put it in the refrigerator.

sxr: rahlooa koacʉkʉhlʉ, makiahlohloako ihlamo mʉmʉa kʉlʉsʉ oomo ooro.
english: It's been a while. Let's have a meal together.

sxr: sianata, miamaako hlitavora, moasaita taraokohla aropakakari.
english: No need to bother. I'll just have tea. Let's sit in the living room and chat.
Thank you for your hospitality. I have to go now.

sxr: hlamona hlipapaci a torokokana, ahlavo koamoamoarao.
english: This chicken was just freshly killed. Take it home and enjoy it slowly.

sxr: aropapiatʉtʉrʉita matata kʉlʉpʉngʉ komamahlipapo toahlʉ i?
english: Can I make an appointment with you tomorrow afternoon?

sxr: aropapiatʉtʉrʉita maro ariatʉkʉrana toahlʉ i? omalaita 'ahlingo.
english: How about meeting at school? We need to shoot a video.

sxr: maci aonana ia ararata'aitamao maro tapohlaihlia, ma hlʉngasʉako mahlokoaisana.
english: Then let's go to the community center. I'll wear folk costume.

sxr: miararomahlamo kiotavahlihlana makaavacangʉ makatavahlihla. maci makatavahlihlaco ia moacʉkʉhlʉkia takoliliongo!
english: The cherry blossoms in our tribe are beautiful when they bloom. Come find me when the flowers bloom!

sxr: maci aonana ia oapapaloco ahlavʉngʉlaia, aonana ia rahloaco angatʉ!
english: That would have to wait until spring. It's too late, isn't it?

sxr: maci aonana ia moacʉkʉhlʉkia maci miatongoso!
english: Then come during our Harvest Festival!
Alright! I'm looking forward to it!

sxr: pakisoahlai tiarao poaili araohloso miararoma mangosipi?
english: May I ask why you decided to move back to the tribe?
I want to return to teach at the local school.
Why not teach in the city?

sxr: ta'iaraisaka malʉngʉngʉako miararomako, ahliako'ai mʉmʉa takoaili miararomako.
english: Because I miss my hometown and I also want to give back to the tribe.

sxr: tam macahliao toraraporo, ngahlaisa hlitomorotoro ihlao?
english: You're very skilled at weaving, who taught you?

sxr: ihlaisa tamoko ahlaina, ihlaisa ma miararomahlamo tam macahlia toraraporo.
english: It was my grandmother, she is the most skilled weaver in our tribe.
How did you develop an interest in learning weaving?

sxr: toraraporona ia ihlaisa sitakoamiahlamo, hlatomoako takoahlosohloso sitakoamiana.
english: Weaving is a part of our culture, and I want to ensure its continuity.

sxr: tam sa'ao a kani'i mapaci hlipico ʉvʉcʉngʉna.

english: You're really talented. Does it take a long time to make?

sxr: sianata, taia'ai ocani taloavaʉlana. moaloalo paocaciri maisikici hla ʉvʉcʉngʉ, hla papohla taamohlo tomitioro, acahlico karaioro tangoroso.
english: No, it only takes about a week. After steaming the sticky rice and white rice, we mix it with yeast powder, and then it can be stored in a jar.

sxr: maaro samʉsamʉmiko hla takʉcʉngʉ, rianʉ hlilimikiko takacicihli!
english: I have chili and lokiy, both grown by myself!
I like this piece of clothing. How much is it?

sxr: tam langʉlangʉ, toahlʉ i marimaini a marikasʉkasʉ?
english: It's too expensive. Can't you lower the price a bit?
No, if I lower it further, I'll lose money.

sxr: hlimini'ai! aonana ia aacaniako tikoro malicʉcʉna.
english: Alright then, I'll take a black piece of clothing.

sxr: tomoako kani'i hlitakʉ hla kani'i tangʉtiana.
english: I want this knife and this pot.

sxr: matarongahlʉ osoa hlimiaili, kani'ina hlitakacicihliko tomamahlʉngʉ, tʉtʉrʉ aroarahloaʉ.
english: It's a total of 2000 dollars. I handmade these, and they are guaranteed to last a long time.

sxr: makiahlohloako tokoco mʉcʉkʉhlʉ po'a, toahlʉ i kopolalangʉlangʉisana?
english: I'll introduce my friend to buy. Can you give a further discount?
Alright! I'll give you a 20% discount.

sxr: moaramao komikita! maaro a tikoro maaro a sarapongo.
english: Come and take a look! We sell clothes and hats.

sxr: ocani tikoro ia otolo hlimiongo malimahlʉ, maci otolo ia ocani hlimiaili vahlitongana.
english: One piece of clothing is 350 dollars, three pieces for 1000 dollars.
I'll just buy one piece, please give me a new one.

sxr: mavacangio, hlatomoako po'a tangosohlo hla papa'a hllilapinga imoo.
english: Hello, I would like to buy sticky rice and braised pork with maqaw pepper.

sxr: pokocoaico a tangosohlo, maromana olongoko tana'ʉ, po'ao i?
english: The rice is sold out. I have tana pancakes, would you like to buy them?

sxr: hlimini'ai! omalako ocani cocoana moangahlangahlako'ai tʉkʉhlʉ ari mʉcʉkʉhlʉ po'a tangosohlo.
english: Alright, please give me one. I'll come back next time to buy rice.

sxr: aa'ʉ, karaiaoroko'ai lovoco, aonani ia malimahlʉ vahlitongana.
english: Okay, I'll pack it in a bag for you. That'll be 50 dollars.

sxr: opito pakiatoroa mosa ko ariatʉkʉrana arinani.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

sxr: omiapʉ co, poaroma tarʉana omiapʉ pakiatoroana, amihla kapitanʉ tarʉana, "mosiri! matitʉnʉlʉ!"
english: It's time for class, the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: "Stand up! Salute!"

sxr: maromaro maci omiiapʉ, tomototoro pakiatoroa ihlahlamo kari tahlana omarocacani.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the Hla′alua language of numbers.

sxr: pialʉvʉ mo pakiatoroa, pahlosahli co a mo sahli omarocacani.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.
I have learned many Hla′alua languages.

sxr: ariari ko omaiiapʉ, ariari ko mosotoro kari tahlana, tomoa ko omahlikoa ina'a tomimahla.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the Hla′alua language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

sxr: maro ko ahlaloa hlahlosa cacihli, pia ʉlʉnganʉ kana'ana, laihla ocani caihli kana'ana mamisa.
english: I have a brother, his name is ʉlʉnganʉ, he is 11 years old.

sxr: kikoco a mo ma ariatʉkʉrana omaiiapʉ.
english: We study in the same school.

sxr: ihlako noa ahlaloa hlahlosa rianʉ maromoko pahlosahli.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

sxr: maromoko ako makahlangolo, maro maci taloavaʉlʉ, kiʉlʉsʉ ocani pihlingi a mo mosa makahlangolo.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

sxr: maromoko ko paotoahlangi laʉlaʉvʉ varo'o, acahli a mo pahlolʉsʉ pahlosahli hla makahlangolo.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

sxr: matarongahlʉ salia hlamo maro coco'o lalima.
english: There are five people in our family.

sxr: salia hlamo maro ahlahlaloa hlimihlimilavaʉ tatolo.
english: There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

sxr: miaʉlʉsʉ ako ama'a, ina'a, ahlaloa hlahlosa noa ahlaloa ahlaina.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.
My father is tall and he is a policeman.

sxr: tam mirihli a inako, maisasavosavoanʉ inako.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

sxr: ma salia macahlia ama'ana pialʉsʉ a mo masi kari tahlana.
english: My father speaks the Hla′alua language with us at home.

sxr: talovaʉlʉ ahlamacicia rianʉ a mo poaili miararoma.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

sxr: matialʉsʉ matiasangalʉ ihlako noa ahlahlaloa tamociakʉ.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

sxr: tam maromoko a ko coco salia hlamo.
english: I like our family very much.

sxr: kipohlo ako noa ina'a pasaolaola'ʉ arinani.
english: I went out with my mother today.

sxr: tam valacoko langica sihlianʉ, koasarʉmʉ koacici langica mʉmʉa, tam matahlʉtʉkʉ varatʉna.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

sxr: mamo ahlahlapa sʉsʉsʉngʉa oomo pangʉ, hlisahlikoa tihla'ahlʉ tahliariana masongoli angatʉ.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

sxr: kʉlʉpʉngʉ mahlipapo aratavohlio co a langica.
english: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

sxr: pakisoahlai ko ina'a, tiaraisa matavohlio a langica.
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.
Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

sxr: oka'a lolonga langica rovana, moromita co a 'acangʉrahlʉ.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

sxr: poaili co a mo salia mʉmʉa.

english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars

sxr: ahli'ai koacʉkʉhlʉ a pariavaratʉ, hlotomoa ko kipohlomana pasaolaola'ʉ.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

sxr: ma patʉkʉ salia hlamo ariatʉkʉrana ko, ariari mosasala ko mahlokoa ariatʉkʉrana, mosasala poaili salia mʉmʉa.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

sxr: ko taisa ariatʉkʉrana hlamo, oka'a tomahlaʉ mamaini omaiiapʉ aropaotoahlangʉ coco mʉmʉa.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

sxr: ma parana sikoatitipa kiakokoco a mamainina, pasaolʉsʉ piataʉhlʉkai, pahlolʉsʉ makakari.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

sxr: macahlia pakiatoroa pasaolʉsʉ hlamo pasaolaola'ʉ mʉmʉa, ihlaisa ia taisa pihlingi ariatʉkʉrana.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

sxr: ariari rianʉ hlamo maivʉtʉraʉ, kiakokoco patapohlipohli tarʉana omiapʉ.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

sxr: maro coco'o sasahli cingarʉ, maro coco'o maivʉtʉraʉ.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

sxr: maivʉtʉraʉ hlamo aocaocani parana 'aratingi, kiakokoco takolʉsʉ tako'i'iarʉ, tam mahlicongo a ariatʉkʉrana ariari.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

sxr: hlimosa ko miararoma takoliliongo tamo hlahlosa kiira
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

sxr: rahloa co a mo koapakita, tam miatatarʉ a ko isana.
english: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

sxr: taratʉahlʉ ko tamo'o hlahlosa, makoakoaisa ihlako oomo vakatʉ maami, makoakoaisa ihlako miama sahlomo rahlʉngʉ.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

sxr: tam maami a hlilʉmʉkʉ isa tamohlahlosana vakatʉ maami, tamooco sa'ao.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

sxr: maromoko a ko tamohlahlosa isa sahlomo rahlʉngʉ mʉmʉa. tam mavacangʉ miima.
english: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

sxr: maromaro maci mahlipapo, pahlaʉlʉsʉ ako noa tamoahlaina avavo koamamahlipapo.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

sxr: hlivavo co tamoahlaina tam marivacangʉ, maro votokohlo, maro torokoka, maro vosiakʉ, maromana tavohlinga.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

sxr: koalʉpʉngʉ koamamahlipapo, mosa mo tatahlatʉngʉa romavi hlatʉngʉ.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

sxr: omala tamoahlaina matomohlo mairangʉ, intavangʉ hla takʉcʉngʉ ovora ihlako, avora ihlako mahlava poaili salia.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.
I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

sxr: roavici pakiatoroa ihlahlamo mosa taopangana kolikolikoli'i, ma mo sipangʉhlʉva patavʉhlʉrʉ po'a cokahlangʉ.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

sxr: molavaʉ poaroma taopangana kolikolikoli'i amihla pakiatoroa, "ahlicovongana ia ngahlana ahlamʉ, ilikosona ngahlana vohli'i, kiakokoco takacicihli komita."
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

sxr: moloahlʉ ko vohli'i, kohlaisai koako komita ngahlana vohli'i.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

sxr: taratʉahlʉ co a ko matomohlo ahlamʉ, ma ahlahlapa kio'o miapipihlihli, taratʉahlʉ mana tapʉ'ʉna ma 'isʉngʉrʉ malosapʉ.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

sxr: taopangana kolikolikoli'i maro kalavongo mʉlʉngʉsʉ ngongoro, tarʉmʉcʉ kavahlʉ noa lokohlo, angahli kiariari konako akita kani'i koli'i, arinani hlikomitaco tamooco masasangarʉ tʉkʉ.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

sxr: hlipitomohlo co a ko 'ahlingo, pakita hlamama ko.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

sxr: mongahlʉ tomoa mʉlʉvʉ hlamama ko mʉcʉkʉhlʉ.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

sxr: talovaʉlana ari kani'i, hlikisoamo ahlaloa ahlaina mosa Taito takoliliongo tamalʉngalʉ.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

sxr: angahli a mo Taipakʉ motatongosa likihli apohlo mosa Taito.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

sxr: miongo co Taito, molikihli tamalʉngalʉna mʉcʉkʉhlʉ otatongosa likihli roavici ihlahlamo.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

sxr: kooasaihla aatʉ otatongosa likihlina saliaisa tamalʉngalʉna, molikihli mo'alivatʉna ia miongo co.
english: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

sxr: lilionga saliaisa tamalʉngalʉ maro tam taisa taopangana 'ivingi, mʉlʉsʉamo likihli omaroa sapahlʉ mosa mahlokoa taopangana 'ivingi.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

sxr: ma taopangana 'ivingi, roavici tamalʉngalʉ amo pao 'okoi noa motatongosa tarʉmʉcʉ kavahlʉ.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

sxr: rovana, koalʉsiamo mosa mahlokoa miararoma ikatomahlama oomao koarovarovana.

sxr: tamtomohlo likihli a miararoma ikatomahlana, kohlaisai molikihliamo likihli omaro 'orai mosa kaaio.

sxr: akoko mainimana koako macahlia tahlana vongoka takacicihli, marino ako mahlikoa cocomaco.

english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: "My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!"

micalivi amo i'a'ana papa'a, amihla cocoi'a'ana, "ngasa po'ao? taisa hla mavʉhlʉ a torokokana arinani, otolo hlimiongo ocani."

sxr: hla amihla cocoi'a'ana tam kolangʉlangʉ, koco toahlʉ mariahlamasʉ.

sxr: patʉkʉ cocoi'a'ana amihla, moara po'a votokohlo ko, taisa hla kolangʉlangʉ votokohlo ko.

english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

sxr: pata'arivongoa hlimilavaʉ hlahlosa poaili amihla, omarilʉmʉlʉmʉ kotoahlico taloavaʉlʉ, mongahlʉ taloavaʉlana ari iniciki poaili.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn't take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

sxr: amihla ama'ana maco a ko arataisa iniciki roavici ihlako mosa.

english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

sxr: komita ama'a romahlaʉ hliolavalava co ko cocoaari mʉrʉcʉka.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

sxr: arataisa co a ko kani'i, mataraingi a ko vooro hla ripasʉ, mʉlʉvʉ ama'a mosa mʉrʉcʉka.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

sxr: maco a poaili miararoma romahlaʉ hlipana koli'i poposoaisana cocotahlana.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

sxr: amihla ama'ana, sia'ʉ'ʉraisa 'ihlaco langica, ovora ihlata matomohlo koli'i.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

sxr: akoisa mosa ariatʉkʉrana romahlaʉ, asapocoako mahlava lovoco.

I didn't bring anything with me.

sxr: akoisa omaiaiapʉ romahlaʉ, polʉsʉako laʉlaʉvʉ komakita sohlatʉ.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

sxr: akoisa kiatarari romahlaʉ, paohli a laʉlaʉvʉ ihlakoa siasohlatʉ hla siasamoso.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

english: The teacher told me, Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!""

sxr: ngahla isa tokoco ko ia Mai, kana'ana ia ihlaisa mʉmʉa mamaini Hla'aloa.
english: My good friend's name is Mai, and he is also an Hla'alua child.
We study together in the Rʉhlʉcʉ tribe.

sxr: karʉkʉhlʉ amo pasaʉlʉsʉ tomimahla hlamama kisoahlahlama, rianʉamo tam macahlia masi kari Hla'aloa.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Hla'alua proficiently.

sxr: tam langicako tam mavʉhlʉ ako mʉmʉa, tam mikasekase hla tam mirihlia Mai.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Mai is short and thin.

sxr: tam koatitipa Mai, tam maromokoa coco'o mʉmʉa kana'ana.
english: Mai is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

I participated in the running competition.

english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

sxr: ocaniika akoko omacʉka romahlaʉ, tapihlosohloso tapikakoa ahliacovongo.

sxr: akoko miongo oalava ia masasangarʉa coco'o mʉmʉa.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

sxr: manikia ko atʉahlʉ hlikicoalo, ocaanika masasangarʉa ko, ta'iaraisaka pasalipingicoako sitarisia.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

sxr: kihlamohlamo a kana'ana ihlahlamo. milaloihli a hlialovona.

sxr: matiangahlangahla a kana'ana romahlaʉ, angahli hlialovo motopiakʉ.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

sxr: hlimahlava a ama'ana papakalavongo hla saviki ovora tamalʉngalʉ.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

sxr: mako tatara noa tamalʉngalʉna aropakakari, matomohlo a hlikihlahlamoisa kana'ana kisoahlahlama.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

english: I said, When your foot gets better

english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn't the old registration method sufficient?

english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.
